Literature Review: Transgender and gender diverse (TGD) youth represent a growing and increasingly visible population that faces unique challenges in terms of mental health and well-being. This literature review aims to explore the current state of research on the mental health of TGD children and adolescents, examining the disparities they face, potential explanations for these disparities, and interventions that may improve their mental health outcomes.Mental health disparities among TGD youth have been well-documented in recent years. A study by Veale et al. (2017) found that TGD adolescents reported significantly higher rates of depression, anxiety, and suicidal ideation compared to their cisgender peers. Similarly, Becerra-Culqui et al. (2018) observed that TGD youth were more likely to be diagnosed with attention deficit disorders, depressive disorders, and autism spectrum disorders than cisgender youth.These disparities extend beyond comparisons with cisgender, heterosexual peers. Research by Connolly et al. (2016) demonstrated that TGD youth experience higher levels of psychological distress than cisgender sexual minority youth, highlighting the unique challenges faced by this population. This finding underscores the importance of considering gender identity as a distinct factor in mental health research and interventions.To explain these disparities, many researchers have turned to the minority stress framework, which posits that stigma, prejudice, and discrimination create a stressful social environment that contributes to mental health problems among marginalized groups. Hendricks and Testa (2012) applied this framework specifically to transgender individuals, arguing that experiences of gender-related discrimination, victimization, and internalized transphobia contribute to poor mental health outcomes.Factors that may increase TGD youth's vulnerability to psychological distress include family rejection, peer victimization, and lack of access to gender-affirming care. Simons et al. (2013) found that family rejection was significantly associated with depressive symptoms and suicidal ideation among transgender adolescents. In the school environment, Greytak et al. (2009) reported that TGD students face high rates of harassment and discrimination, which can negatively impact their mental health and academic performance.Conversely, several protective factors have been identified that may decrease TGD youth's vulnerability to psychological distress. Olson et al. (2016) found that socially transitioned transgender children who were supported in their gender identity had normative levels of depression and only slightly elevated anxiety, suggesting that family support and social transition can have positive effects on mental health. Additionally, McConnell et al. (2016) demonstrated that community connectedness and pride in one's gender identity were associated with better psychological well-being among TGD youth.Interventions aimed at improving mental health outcomes for TGD youth have gained increasing attention in recent years. Gender-affirming medical care, including puberty suppression and gender-affirming hormones, has shown promise in alleviating gender dysphoria and improving mental health. A landmark study by de Vries et al. (2014) found that TGD adolescents who received puberty suppression, followed by gender-affirming hormones and surgery, had psychological functioning comparable to the general population in adulthood.Psychosocial interventions have also been developed to address the unique needs of TGD youth. Austin et al. (2018) described a group-based intervention that combined cognitive-behavioral therapy with transgender-specific content, which showed promising results in reducing anxiety and depression symptoms. Furthermore, school-based interventions, such as the implementation of inclusive policies and staff training, have been associated with improved mental health outcomes for TGD students (Day et al., 2018).Despite the growing body of research on TGD youth mental health, several limitations and gaps in the literature persist. Many studies rely on small, non-representative samples, limiting the generalizability of findings. Longitudinal research is scarce, making it difficult to establish causal relationships between risk factors, protective factors, and mental health outcomes. Additionally, there is a need for more research on intersectionality, examining how multiple marginalized identities (e.g., race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status) interact with gender identity to influence mental health.Future research should prioritize larger, more diverse samples and longitudinal designs to better understand the trajectories of mental health among TGD youth. There is also a need for more studies on resilience and positive mental health outcomes, as well as research on the effectiveness of various interventions across different cultural contexts.In conclusion, the mental health of TGD youth remains a critical area of concern and research. While significant disparities exist, emerging evidence suggests that supportive environments, gender-affirming care, and targeted interventions can improve mental health outcomes for this vulnerable population. As our understanding of TGD youth mental health continues to evolve, it is crucial that researchers, clinicians, and policymakers work together to develop and implement evidence-based strategies to support the well-being of TGD children and adolescents.
